page.title: 12VALE OF CLWYD.LANGUAGE.
page.content: It seems to our researchers that if families have lived in the area for a number of generations,they are likely to be Welsh -speaking.If one of the partners is English,the language of the home is likely to be English.Newcomers to the area are almost certain to be non-Welsh speakers.Although{English {=60%,Welsh=40%,}we include a collection of country sayings(with translation)still in use.{Haidd i'r {llwch a gwenith i'r mwd}.Sow barley in dust,wheat in mud{.Os chwythi'r {arno,bydd rhy sych.Os poeri'r {arno,bydd yn rhy wlyb}.Blow on it,and it's too dry.Spit on it and it's too wet.(300 yrs. old-about Vale of Clwyd land){Gwyn y gwel y fran ei chyw.}A crow always sees her chick as white{Yn {aradeg mae dal iar}.It's very slowly you catch a hen.
